title: Wednesday, 31st August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

11:02 am

I'm going to nip in a dish Pokemon GO

PM

It's a stupid fad, right

PM

But some people still pretending it's some wonderful game changer

11:03 am
PM

Virtual reality -- gonna change the way we live and shop etc

PM

It's rubbish

PM

Guff like this...

11:03 am
PM

Unless you’ve been living under a Poké Ball the last several weeks, you’ve undoubtedly heard of the new app-based game and overnight sensation Pokémon GO. As one of the first location-based augmented reality games, Pokémon GO mimics your actual “real world” surroundings using a Google Maps-like interface as you seek to find and capture Pokémon characters.
The app was released in early July, and in its first full month of reporting, data from comScore Mobile Metrix® showed that it ranked as the 9th largest mobile app in the UK with 9.5 million unique visitors across smartphone and tablet. This represents 30% of the total mobile app population, even edging out a couple of social media heavyweights for the month.

PM

For as long as comScore has been measuring digital audiences, there really isn’t even a remotely comparable instance of a website or app capturing such a large audience in such a short period of time. Perhaps even more impressive for Pokémon GO is the high level of engagement it’s seeing. In its first month, the app also ranked 5th in total app time spent, behind only Facebook, Google, BBC Sites and Apple Inc. In addition, well over a quarter of its user base visited on a daily basis, suggesting that its audience was highly engaged with the app throughout the month and doesn’t just represent a bunch of curious lurkers.

PM

Really?

11:04 am
PM

So why...

PM

PM

It's not even in the Top 10 for free downloads

11:04 am
PM

It's a fad and it's over

PM

People downloaded. Tried it. Some got obsessed for a day or two. And then people realised it was stupid

11:07 am

Which is replicated in Germany -- but not the rest of Europe

PM

PM

11:07 am
PM

Here's some ING

PM

The Eurozone inflation rate was stable at 0.2% in August, lower than analysts had expected. The core inflation rate even dropped from 0.9% to 0.8%, indicating that the inflation rate in the Eurozone is stuck in neutral as the oil price effect is fading out of the data. This should at the very least put upward pressure on the headline rate, but with disappointing price growth in services, inflation is staying put for the moment.

With nominal wage growth still weak, it is difficult to see core inflation move anywhere near the “just under 2%” target of the ECB. Wage pressures are unlikely to emerge in the coming months as unemployment is still elevated. Today’s release of the July the unemployment rate, which was stable at 10.1%, confirms that significant wage pressure is unlikely to return at least before the end of the year, as this still leaves unemployment well above its natural rate for the moment.

PM

Businesses are also still fighting for volumes, which results in continued low prices. But now that producer prices have been rising in the past months, the question remains how long businesses can continue to pass on low production prices to the consumer. Yesterday’s Economic Sentiment Indicator for the Eurozone revealed that businesses are not worried about rising production prices as of yet though as they indicated to be expecting further price declines over the coming months.

It is unlikely that the ECB will act on the drop in core inflation at its meeting next week. Next week’s meeting of the governing council will focus mostly on the staff projections that have been made earlier and we therefore expect that no further easing will be announced, except for perhaps a drop of the deposit rate floor of the government bond purchases. The fact that core inflation is now lower than it was a year ago will be alarming to ECB governing council members though, especially as economic activity seems to be slowing further in the third quarter on political and economic uncertainty.

11:08 am
PM

And a bit from Stephen Brown at Cap Economics

PM

The unchanged headline inflation rate in August highlights the fact that price pressures in the euro-zone remain weak and boosts the case for more monetary easing from the ECB. Headline harmonised (HICP) inflation was unchanged at +0.2% in August. The consensus forecast was for a rise to 0.3%, although expectations will have fallen after yesterday’s weaker-than-expected German inflation. Inflation was unchanged despite an easing of the drag from energy prices, with energy inflation increasing from -6.7% to -5.7%% in August. Instead, core (ex. food and energy) inflation dropped back from 0.9% to 0.8%. Goods inflation fell from 0.4% to 0.3% and services inflation fell from 1.2% to 1.1%.

PM

nless energy prices drop back sharply, headline HICP inflation will rise over the coming months. But core price pressures are likely to remain weak. Indeed, other data released this morning revealed that there is still a large amount of spare capacity in the labour market, with the euro-zone unemployment rate unchanged at 10.1% in July. That was weaker than the consensus expectation of a drop to 10.0%. The unemployment rate is well above its 1999 to 2007 average of 8.8%, indicating that there is a large amount of slack in the economy and suggesting that wage pressures will remain subdued. With yesterday’s survey data also pointing to a marked slowdown in growth ahead, there is a strong case for the ECB to announce further policy easing. This could come as soon as the Bank’s meeting next week.

Subsequent to the EU Referendum result on 23 June 2016, corporate bond yields have decreased materially in the UK and, as this yield is used to discount the Group's pension liability under IAS 19 "Employee Benefits", if the corporate bond yield remains at its current low level then this will result in a significant increase in the Group's pension deficit as at 30 September 2016. This likely increased IAS 19 pension deficit would have the effect of extinguishing the Company's available distributable reserves, in which case the Company will not be able to pay the final dividend of 1.95 pence per share, declared on 7 June 2016, on 7 October 2016 to those members that were on the register at 26 August 2016. Whilst the Board is disappointed that the final dividend is now unlikely to be capable of being paid due to these legal and accounting constraints, it intends to resume the Company's progressive dividend policy once legal and accounting circumstances allow.

11:20 am
BE

Though there's not much that can be said, really. Here's David Buxton at Finncap.

BE

The AGM statement provided a reassuring view of current trading, with H1 trading on track to be in line with FY forecasts. Technical Plastics has had a good start to the year, with healthcare demand as expected. Due to an award of additional volume production from an established customer management has approved the expansion of its Indian facility, expected to be completed by summer 2017. Traction with new customers is building in China. LED Technologies (WIPAC) has also traded well, with new design and development programmes progressing as planned, with the new business pipeline also progressing as planned. Optics has seen strong demand. The Aerospace operation has traded in line, experiencing stable demand conditions. As a result of recent sterling weakness the group’s US$ and Euro debt has a negative translation effect on the level of reported net debt, which is expected to now be £27m at the half year and £26m by the full year. There is to be a small gain on profit translation of around £200k. Following the Brexit vote, the corporate bond yield has fallen significantly. As this is used to calculate the group’s pension liabilities, there will be a rise in its IAS19 pension deficit. Unfortunately, this will wipe out distributable reserves and, by company law, this prohibits the company paying a dividend. No change to trading forecasts; however, we eliminate the dividend both this year and next until such time as the corporate bond rate enables a reduction in pension liabilities and thus gives sufficient distributable reserves. This is a disappointment, but beyond management control. While the shares have not been on the high yield list and therefore the share register is not made up of income funds, it is nevertheless likely to affect the shares in the short term. This is especially galling given the underlying trading position is satisfactory and progressing as planned. For the time being we reduce our target price from 195p to 150p and therefore reduce our rating to Hold.

BE

Singer also downgrade, saying nothing. Peel Hunt remain buyers.

11:21 am
BE

The Group has enjoyed a strong start to the year with continued
momentum within the two largest divisions. In the short term,
this is overshadowed by news that the reduction in corporate
bond yields and subsequent increase in the IAS19 pension
deficit, is now expected to prevent dividend distribution.
However, we remain focused on the capacity expansion and new
business pipeline that underpins our strong PBT growth forecasts
to March 2019. With the shares trading on a Mar'17 PER of
14.1x, falling to 12.0x Mar'18, we are maintaining our 190p
target price and Buy recommendation.

BE

The next triennial review of the pension deficit is not due until March 2018, with
the negotiations with the pension trustees unlikely to conclude before early 2019.
As a result, we do not anticipate any change in the pension deficit reduction
payments in the near-term. Net of the FX translation headwind and reduced
cash outflow with respect to the dividend, we have trimmed our year-end net
debt forecasts by £0.4m to £25.6m. If no dividend is declared in respect of
FY2017, net debt is now forecast to reduce to £21.5m at March 2018, less than
1.2x EBITDA.

BE

(@TheLimey, on consideration, I'm minded to agree. Pensioners before shareholders seems to be a fair order of priorities.)

At the recent 1H results, management suggested group trading was in line with previous FY16 guidance. The first phase of the strategic review focusing on the Frankie & Benny’s offer has been completed identifying a number of issues, particularly around the menu, which the group is in the early stages of addressing. The business will now look to review the remaining Leisure brands as well as the Pubs and Concessions.

11:25 am
BE

As well as the issues highlighted regarding the offer, the group also announced plans to close 33 sites and write down the asset value on a further 29. In total the group took a £59.1m exceptional charge (£19m cash costs).

BE

As per our recent note Valuation Supportive, But Headwinds Remain we maintain our view that, whilst there may be valuation support on a SOTP basis, Restaurant Group still faces significant trading headwinds, with limited near-term positive catalysts. Whilst we think recent management appointments of a new CFO and CEO are positive steps in the group’s rehabilitation, we suggest there could be further store closures and exceptional costs as new management looks to revitalize the Leisure operations.

BE

Within the note we revise our estimates for Restaurant Group following the recent 1H16 results. We largely maintain our FY16 revenue forecasts whilst reducing FY17E by and FY18E revenues by -1% following changes to our LFL and store opening assumptions. We also update our group cost assumptions, reducing FY16E EPS by 1%, with FY17E cut by 10% and FY18E by 8%.

11:26 am
BE

Following our updated estimates we reduce our DCF-derived price target reducing to 320p (from 350p). Restaurant Group’s share price has bounced over 50% of late. Given this significant move, and our view that the group faces ongoing operational headwinds, we downgrade the stock to Sell, with an ETR of -16%.

PM

BE

I mention DNO largely because, in the week we were off, its management came to London to talk about the punt at GKP.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

DNO management, including Executive Chairman Bijan Mossavar-Rahmani and CFO Haakon Sandborg, hosted an analyst dinner in London last week. Discussion centered on M&A, Tawke and a geo-political update. Key takeaways: 1) DNO believes the asset market bid-offer spread has narrowed and is as close as it has been during the current oil price downturn, 2) the company is actively looking at assets outside of its heartlands, its acquisition strategy is not reliant on a successful GKP bid, 3) DNO’s ambitions for GKP over the near/medium term are perhaps more modest than we might have thought, and 4) if export payments at Tawke continue at current levels (i.e. in line with invoices), then there is potential for a significant step up in investment on the field in 2017 (perhaps as high as double 2016 capex, i.e. ~$200m).

BE

Note, this is from August 22. But we'd not shared it before, and it's incrementally interesting I guess.

11:35 am
BE

 M&A – GKP. The Gulf Keystone bid is centered on DNO’s belief that its local knowledge and experience, region-specific synergies (infrastructure, offices etc) and superior balance sheet, offer operational and financial upside.
o Quite reasonably DNO believes that some of Shaikan’s development learnings could be readily transferred on to its own heavy oil fields in Kurdistan, Benenan and Bastora.
o Somewhat surprisingly DNO’s ambitions for Shaikan are not huge – in the first instance it will focus on understanding the field and delivering stable and profitable production at c.50 kbopd, which is not all that far above current rates (that ambition may increase with time). We note that Shaikan is not seen by management as a source of funding for future Tawke reinvestment.
o DNO would like to develop an alternative export route for Shaikan’s heavy crude (to the Iraq Turkey Pipeline) as it has a view that increased output from Shaikan, could lead to it having too great a negative effect on the quality of the Kirkuk blend at Ceyhan.
o Bid timing – DNO suggested that the timing of its approach was driven by a desire to be in front of future owners of the business during the recapitalization process. There is no specific timing on the expiry of its offer, but DNO is pushing for irrevocable undertakings from bond and note holders during September in order to give them clarity over whether its approach would be likely to succeed or not.

BE

 M&A – Other opportunities. DNO was clear that GKP is not its only opportunity and, in our view, it is evident the company is actively looking to diversify. DNO believes that oil price assumptions baked in to seller asset valuations have moderated and, as a result, the asset market bid-offer spread has tightened, closer than at any other point during this oil price downturn. It follows, therefore, that DNO currently sees more opportunities that meet its acquisition criteria.
o What are the criteria? In terms of size, it is not clear – although it would have to be big enough to stand against Tawke and factor in the overall valuation.
o DNO is looking for producing or near production assets, with no apparent bias over oil or gas.

BE

Etc.

Elena Fournadjieva – Executive Director
Ms Fournadjieva, aged 51, is a Bulgarian national and has a Masters Degree in Russian Philology from Sofia University, Bulgaria and a Masters Degree in Law from Veliko Tarnovo University, Bulgaria. Ms Fournadjieva worked from 1993 to 2006 as a Senior Administrative Assistant for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. From 2006 – 2009, Ms Fournadjieva was the Head of Legal and the Administrative department of East Balkan Properties PLC (formerly Equest Balkan Properties PLC). East Balkan Properties PLC was previously an AIM listed property fund with investments in Bulgaria, Romania, Macedonia and Serbia. Since 2006, Ms Fournadjieva has provided investment fund management and administration services for Trans Balkan Investment LTD (formerly Equest Investment Balkans PLC). In addition, Ms Fournadjieva is the sole owner of Lexington Management Services EOOD. Lexington EOOD’s main activity is the provision of corporate services.

BE

Rather less curious, we have Goldman downgrading Morrison.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 196.00, down 1.3 (-0.66%), High: 197.80, Low: 192.00, Volume: 5.11m
11:52 am
BE

Part of a rather long and not exactly thrill-packed sector note.

BE

European food retail has outperformed Stoxx 600
11% YTD and now trades at a 15% premium.
While volume growth has been a focus, food
inflation has historically been the driver of sector
growth and relative valuation. However, with food
CPI still low in many markets and the gap with
input costs closing, valuations look stretched to
us. We remain cautious on the space.

BE

1H16 was a very strong period for margins across
the sector with divisional margins up c.46 bp on
average. Our Food Retail barometer shows this
was driven by consumer prices rising faster than
input costs, with the CPI-PPI spread c.200 bp on
average across the markets we focus on vs the 5
year average of 30 bp. However, the latest data
points show this has already narrowed to 100 bp
and we only forecast average EBIT margin
expansion of 8 bp in 2H. The UK looks the most
pressured market with the July CPI-PPI spread at
-5.2%, reflecting structural difficulties in passing
through rising input costs.

11:53 am
BE

Interesting bit!

BE

Amazon Prime Now launched in Paris and is 7%-
34% cheaper than physical stores. However, we
think the incumbent grocers could prove to be the
most disruptive. Our surveys shows Drive stores
within 10km of central Paris are more than 25% cheaper
than central Paris stores, meaning this market
could be most impacted by the price transparency
online brings. With c.40% of its stores in Paris, we
are most concerned about profits at Casino’s
Monoprix business. At c.70% of 2016E EBIT ex
property in France, a 1% fall in Monoprix’s
margins decreases our Casino valuation by 14%.

BE

I'll come back to how much things cost in Paris, because it's mildly interesting in the scheme of things.

11:54 am
BE

Stock wise though .....

BE

We reinstate Casino with a Sell rating (12m TP
€40) and are 5% below FY16E Bloomberg
consensus EBIT. We downgrade Morrisons to Sell,
and are 5% below FY18E Vuma consensus PBT.
We downgrade Jeronimo to Neutral and reinstate
Ahold Delhaize and Metro at Neutral. Ex-Ocado
12m PTs for our store-based food retail coverage
imply an average of 4% downside potential.

BE

So ................

11:55 am
BE

With significant levels of price discrimination between location and format seen across France (Casino’s Monoprix stores are over 20% more expensive than their hypermarkets), we believe the price transparency of a compelling home delivery model could be very disruptive in France. Though we don’t believe Amazon Prime’s recent launch will be this disruptive force in the short to medium term, we believe incumbent grocers have the opportunity to significantly disrupt the Parisian grocery market through home
delivery.
Because of the focus on Drive (Click and Collect) in France, we believe Paris is unique amongst large cities in well developed online markets in under indexing in online grocery. However, given our price survey shows Carrefour Drives are c.25% cheaper than shops
in central Paris, less than 10km away (and greater than 20% cheaper than Carrefour’s current home delivery option), even with a €10 delivery charge, a home delivery option with the range of a market leader’s hypermarket could serve Paris residents far cheaper than their current store offers. For predominantly hypermarket operators with minimal Paris exposure like Leclerc or Auchan we believe this could be a low capital solution to driving sales and extracting profits from a Parisian market their formats have had restricted access
to before. With c.40% of its stores located in and around Paris, we are most concerned about profits at Casino’s Monoprix business.

BE

Or as charts ........

BE

11:56 am
BE

As to Morrison .............

BE

We downgrade Morrisons from Neutral to Sell. Though we continue to believe Morrisons should be rewarded for its commitment to price investments, cost cutting and cash generation, we believe this is more than reflected in the stock price and see no room in consensus for the worsening conditions we forecast in the UK grocery market. We do not expect a negative surprise at 1H17 results on September 15, but, given the stock’s recent
outperformance (in the last month (YTD in brackets) MRW +10% (+34%), SBRY +8% (-6%), TSCO +2% (+10%)), we believe the stock is already reflecting this. The stock is now trading on a significant P/E premium to its history vs the market and vs peers (see Exhibit 78) – Morrisons P/E is trading at a 7% premium to our European Food
Retail coverage. While we see some of this as justified, given LFL momentum and balance sheet improvement, we believe the valuation and consensus are reflecting best-case scenarios with market risks heightening, in our view. As we highlight above, our key concern is that UK input costs are rising yet structural pressures mean these are not being passed through to consumers. CPI less PPI in July at -5.2% was the most negative we have seen it in over five years and is now in sharp contrast to the positive levels seen across 2015 and early 2016. In addition to this, we believe the threat from Asda doing something aggressive to disrupt the UK grocery market is now at its highest. It has recently appointed a new CEO and LFL sales are the worst on record. We believe any meaningful response from Asda would negatively impact industry margins. Against this, we believe consensus
expectations for operating margins at Morrison to expand 30bp FY16-19E are overly optimistic. Consequently, we are 5% and 8% below FY18 and FY19 Vuma consensus PBT, respectively. With c.12% downside to our new 12m price target of 175p (180p), we downgrade the stock to Sell.

BE

Which is plenty, right? And enough, I think.
